_prev_prog_3.Description:
The CF Woodward Plant has a comprehensive Safety-Loss Prevention/Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's standard for process management of highly hazardous chemicals found in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.



Key elements of the PSM program include:  1) stringent design of equipment which incorporates substantial safety factors and include state of the art monitoring and control instrumentation; 2) extensive process safety information that is accurate and up to date; 3) well trained operating, maintenance and contract personnel; 4) written safety, operating, and maintenance procedures; 5) mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control; 6) management of change and pre-startup review procedures; 7) periodic, detailed evaluation of each process area by a team utilizing HAZOP methodology; 8) regular PSM program audits; and 9) employee participation in every element of the PSM program.



The Woodward Plant process is nitrogen product manufacturing facility which consists of seven interconnected and co-located production/storage units.  These units have similar prevention program elements and are listed together in Section 7.  The units and their updated PHA dates are as follows:  



Ammonia Plant- Revalidation February 2020

Urea Ammonium Nitrate Plant #1 - Revalidation February 2018

Urea Ammonium Nitrate Plant #2 - Revalidation April 2019

Nitric Acid Plant #1 - Revalidation February 2018

Nitric Acid Plant #2 - Revalidation April 2019

Offsights/Utilities Systems - Revalidation September 2016 

Ammonia Storage and Loading - Revalidation January 2019

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Operating in a safe and responsible manner is a core value and an integral part of CF Industries. Our safety strategy revolves around our "Do It Right" value and permeates our business in three key ways:

?    Robust systems that provide a clear, repeatable direction toward excellence.

?    Superior performance that aligns effective and efficient EHS activities with operations.

?    Engaged culture that empowers consistent behaviors that drive toward excellence.

CF Industries works closely with emergency responders and other local officials to develop detailed emergency response plans that extend beyond our physical operating locations.



CF WOODWARD PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The CF Woodward Plant (Woodward, Oklahoma) manufactures anhydrous ammonia, urea solutions, urea ammonium nitrate solution and by-product gaseous carbon dioxide. Intermediates in the manufacture of the products include nitric acid, and ammonium nitrate solution. The regulated substance, as defined by 40 CFR Part 68, which is present at the facility in more than a threshold quantity is ammonia.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Woodward Plant has taken all the necessary steps to comply with all of the accidental release and chemical-specific prevention requirements as set forth in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR Part 68. This facility is also subject to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119. The following summarizes the elements of the release and chemical-specific prevention that are in place at our facility:

?    Process safety information that is accurate and up to date;

?    Well-trained operating, maintenance, and contract personnel;

?    Written operating procedures;

?    Mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control;

?    Management of change and pre-startup safety review proc

responders and local officials, recognition programs and participation in industry safety initiatives help keep our focus on what it takes to "Do It Right." Through our ongoing commitment to make our facility as safe as possible for employees, contractors, the community, and the environment, we are always continuously improving our systems and practices.
